prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 - C34.2 - eps cha
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose ALMA continuum and spectroscopic observations (12CO) observations of the cluster members of eps cha not detected or not observed in our preparatory survey we have carried out with APEX/LABOCA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Continuum at 335GHz with a band width of 31.25MHz. Do not overlap the CO line, which is most abundant molecule in protoplanetary disks. We require an angular resolution of 0.59".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 - C34.7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose ALMA continuum (870 micron) and lines (12CO and C18O) observations in Band 7 of a complete and unbiased survey of all the members of eps Cha and eta Cha. ALMA is the only submillimeter facility which allows to reach the stellar photospheres of the all clusters members at a distance of about 100 pc. We used LABOCA/APEX to carry out a preparatory survey on the members detected in the mid-infrared excess of eps Cha and the eta Cha clusters. We request observations in Band 7 to obtain continuum at 870 micron (as the preparatory survey we have carried out with APEX/LABOCA). Sources not yet observed or not not detected with LABOCA will be observed in a shorter configuration (C34.2) an angular resolution of 0.59''. This configuaration allow us only to barely detect disks with an outer radius of about 100AU, and hence to increase the signal-to-noise on the detection. We require also the observation of the 12CO, which is the most abundant molecule present in Band 7 observed in protoplanetary disks. For this reason this is the most appropriate molecule to detect gas protoplanetary disks. Since however the line is optically thick, to estimate the gas mass, we ask for the C18O as well, which is instead optically thin.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request continuum observation at 342.92GHz with a band width of 31.25MHz. We require also 13CO at 330.55 GHz and C18O at 329.29 GHz. The continuum has been accurately chosen in order to not overlap the CO line, which is most abundant molecule in protoplanetary disks. We require an angular resolution of 0.12", necessary to resove the disk. In this configuration the 13CO is one of the most suitable molecule to find signature of gas in a protoplanetary disk. The C18O is requested because it allows us to compute the gas mass.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 - C34.2 - eta cha
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose ALMA continuum and spectroscopic observations (12CO) observations of the cluster members of eta cha not detected or not observed in our preparatory survey we have carried out with APEX/LABOCA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Continuum at 335GHz with a band width of 31.25MHz. Do not overlap the CO line, which is most abundant molecule in protoplanetary disks. We require an angular resolution of 0.59".

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 - C34.2 - eps cha_Halo
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose ALMA continuum and spectroscopic observations (12CO) observations of the new cluster members of eps cha from the paper of Murphy et al. 2013 not detected or not observed in our preparatory survey we have carried out with APEX/LABOCA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Continuum at 335GHz with a band width of 31.25MHz. Do not overlap the CO line, which is most abundant molecule in protoplanetary disks. We require an angular resolution of 0.59".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a study of the complete and unbiased sample of all young stars in two nearby associations, epsilon Cha and eta Cha, with the aim of characterizing the dispersion and evolution of circumstellar disks. The two clusters form an extremely well characterized, complete and unbiased sample of T Tauri and Vega-type stars with ages between 5 and 8 Myr. ALMA photometric observations will provide unique constraints on the disk structure, mass and dissipation of the circumstellar disks. Combining the ALMA observations with the available observations at different wavelengths we will observationally constrain the dissipation mechanism in protoplanetary disks. 12CO contemporaneous observations will enable us to constrain the fraction of members with dust and gas, and relate them to the mass accretion rate. We aim also at resolving protoplanetary disks around the transitional object, RECX 5, and the Class II disk around RECX 11. These are the brightest sources detected in our APEX/LABOCA survey. Spectroscopic observations of the 13CO and C18O lines will allow the study of the differences in dust and gas distribution in a classical Class II and a transitional disk.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
